message: واحد بدأ مجموعة من البلوج بوستس علشان يشرح ازاى تعمل لغة روبى بالC من الأول خالص.
name: Reconstructing Ruby, Part 1: Our First Lexer
caption: www.halogenandtoast.com
description: halogenandtoast06 Aug 2014Reconstructing Ruby, Part 1: Our First LexerPlease read my introduction to this series to find out more about it.The first step in writing our implementation of Ruby is to create a lexer. What is a lexer? The job of a lexer is to read your code and identify what we call tok…

data.message: Now, that is hardcore. I got mixed feelings when I saw Flex, though. Good stuff, but reminds me of horrible college days :)

In college, I used a tool called pyggy (parser generator for Python). We were able to finish the project faster than all the teams who used lex + yacc. I was able to convince 2 other teams to use it & their result was good as well. In the next year the TA responsible for the project told the students that Python was not acceptable (your batch I believe Ahmed T. Al-Amir)
I would need someone from my batch to confirm that, I hardly ever attended :D

This is a bad start, the writer needs to define the language specifications and gives the big picture first. Usually, compiler implementation requires defining the language (in BNF format) and then work from there ... the main steps are lexical analysis (using lex or flex, the purpose of this article) and parser (something like yacc) ..
I don't consider this article as C implementation, it's more like using flex (and probably yacc or the like in future). Some of C implementation aspects will be memory management, efficient garbage collection, etc...
but it reminds me with college anyway :D
